\x03\x01\x11\x00\x02\x11\x01\x03\x11\x01\xff\xc4\x00\xbd\x00\x00\x00\x07\x01\x01\x01\x01\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x02\x03\x04\x05\x06\x07\x08\x01\t\x00\n\x01\x00\x02\x03\x01\x01\x01\x01\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x01\x02\x03\x04\x05\x06\x07\x08\x10\x00\x02\x01\x03\x02\x04\x04\x04\x03\x06\x04\x04\x03\x07\x02\x07\x01\x02\x03\x00\x11\x04!\x051A\x12\x06Qa\x13\x07q\x81"\x14\x912\x08\xa1\xb1BR#\x15\xc1\xd1b3rC$\x16\xe1\x824\xf0\xf1\x92ScD%\x17\t\xa2\xb2\x83T56\x18\x11\x00\x02\x02\x01\x04\x00\x04\x04\x04\x04\x04\x05\x03\x05\x01\x00\x00\x01\x11\x02\x03!1\x12\x04AQ\x13\x05aq"\x06\x81\x912\x14\xa1\xb1\xc1B\xf0\xd1#\x07\xe1Rb3\x15\xf1\x92Cr\x82$4\x16\xa2\xff\xda\x00\x0c\x03\x01\x00\x02\x11\x03\x11\x00?\x00\xf3a\xf4\xd3\x9dy}\xcfF\x84Is\x92\x9e\x1a\xd4\xaaA\x8a\xb2\xaf\xd2\r\xb5\xbf*lHB\x0e\x9e\x1f:I\x0c\x0b\x9b\x0b\r4\xa6\x12\x1f\xb2l{\x97sn\xf8{.\xd3\t\x9f75\xc2(\x1c\x14_V>B\xb4u\xf0[5\x95QVK\xaa)g\xa8\xbe\xcb\xfe\x96{w\xb7q17-\xe7\x113\xb7\'P\xd9\x19\x13 \'\xab\xc1o\xc2\xbdV\x0e\xad0\xa8KS\x93\x97#\xbb\x96\xf4\xf26&>\x06\xc9\xb0\xe3$8x\xb1G\xe9\x8b\x00\xaa\x05\xad\xf0\xadFgq\x87r\xeex\xb1\x83\x95`\x81u\xb0\xe3P\xb5\xa1\x11\x92\x8f\xee\xefv\xf26\xe0\xe9\x06AV\xb6\x965\xcc\xcf\xdb\x82\xdac\x93,w\x9f\xbe\xb9P$\xd2d\xee-\xce\xeb\xd5\\\xbb\xe6\xb5\xd9\xaa\xb8\xeb]Y\x92\xfb\xbf\xf5\'\x98\x1aX\xb0r\\\xbd\xcd\xbaX\xd3\xa7]\xbd\xc2\xd9R\xd8\xa0\xb7\x9fy;\xbfuw#t\x9a$\'\x93\x9b\xd6\x8a\xf5\xea\x8a\x9d\xdb\x1a\xf0}\xc7\xee4\x0f\x0evc\xe7c\xcd\xa3\t\r\xca\xf9\x82jO\x12\xf0%[\xb42\xcb2n{\xb6$\x8c\xd6\xea\x94}\\\xf54\xde\x89\x86\xec\xf4\x13\xd9\x1e\xc1\x87\xbaw,,\x8c\xb0%\xc0\xdb\x82\xf5\\hZ\xb0\xf4\xf1r\xbb\xb35f\xbcW\x8a=\x13\x8bq\xed\xfe\xd1\xdbc\x89\n+\x90\x16$\x16\xb9<+\xd0V\x0cW\xba\xaa%\x1d\xb3\xdb\xa3\xb9\xbaw\x0c\xd5>\x83\x1e\xa5B+Mi\xe2\xcc\xf3\xcbR\xdb\xc5\x83k\xd8\x91c\x82\x14R\x05\xb4\x02\xac\x80v\x80\xe9\xb7\xa6qp@\x00h\x05\x10FH\xdeot\x18\x89\x01\xf5\x15\x1b8\x1a*\xde\xeb\xf7*M\xb5\x1cG/K\x01{\x93Xs\xf68\xa2\xca\xd6L\xad\xde\xbe\xf6\xee0\xc5)\x9b1\x84B\xfaur\xaeM\xfb\x16\xc8i\xae(\xdc\xc9=\xcf\xfa\x95\xcb\xc7\x96T\xc7\xcbi\x1a\xe4X\x1a\x8dp\xb7\xb8\xfdH)\xad\xc7\xf5\x11\xdd\xd92\x1fK)\x82\\\xd9oV\xfe\xdd=\xc8\xfa\x8d\x17\xcf\xb3\x1f\xa9([.\r\xbf~\x9b\xed\xb2\x19\x82\xa3\xb9\xfa\x1a\xfef\xb8^\xe7\xed\xf6_UuGc\xa1\xdd\xaa\xfalz!\xdb\x9e\xe1\xe0nP\xc41\xf2\x95K\x81b\r\xc1\xbdp\x16;&w=D\xcb\x7fc\xc2L\xfe\x9c\x8c\x90%C\xaa\x9e5&J\xa2\xce\xe88X\x98\x12\xacq\xa8%\x08\x1ayR\x89cw\x84a\x1d\xd3\xb5{\xcb|\xef\x18\xe4\xed\x8c\x991\xdf\xd5\x1dj\xa4\xf4\xda\xfct\xae\x8fW\xaf{\xd9%\xe2s\xbb\x17\xaa\\\x8fM}\xa2\xed-\xd7g\xd9\xb1\x0e\xf7\x91$\xf9a\x07\xaa\xeex\x9bW\xb2\xea{mq)z\xb3\x81\x9b\xb7f\\YYqF\n!\xd0\x0e<\xab\xa5Z$`wl\x86n\xbb\xe4\x18H\xce\xcc\x14\rX\x9f\n,\xe0\x11\x9a=\xc3\xf7g\xed\xe3\x96\x1ci\xadk\x85\x00\xf1\xaegg\xb5\xc7D]J6d\xdd\xf3\xbd\xf3s\xe6wy:\x83\x9d\x16\xb97\xbb\xb1\xb2\xb5\x82\xbc\xdfv\x9cn\xe3\xc7oY\x17\xacq\xd2\xa1\x1a\x16\xa6Bb\xedX\xb6\xd4\x92 \x08\x85\xc1\n</\\>\xcaj\xc7c\xae\xd7\x1d\x0c\xbb\xee\xe6\xd06\xa3,\xf1\xc9\xc3Pkw\xb7Zm\x06>\xf5aIA\xc3\xb9\x9c\x96\x89db\xc4s5\xdex\xb8\x9c\x9fS\x91kl\xf96\xdb\x82_\xf2\x82+;Z\x96\xd5\xe8m\xaf\xd1\xaf\xb4\x18\xfb\xb6fg{nX\x82l\x8d\xc7 \xa6\x0bH\xb7\xe8\x81\r\xae?\xe2:\xd6\xde\xady9\xf0E:I\xebl\xbe\x87o\xed\xb1\xe2@\xa22\x13P+{pSg&x\xef\xad\xdeI\x16[?\x1b\xf3\xaaoa$d\x9e\xee\xdcD\x89\'S_\x8e\x86\xb9\xf9\x9c\x9aq\xe8Q1\xbf\xab\x9b!C\xa5\xf4\x15\x89\xa2\xf2e\x83\x90\xf8\xfd\x02\xe7^"\x88\x13$\xb6\\\xd8J\xb5\x89#CP`\xb4*\xbe\xe6\xd9\xbd7\xf5\x118q\xaa\xd8\xd9\x07X\xacZ\xc2\xd6\xe3P\xb0\xd0\xb6%\xe1j\xa5\x92\x1f\xf0\xb4 \\\xeau\xaa\xc9\x12|v\xb1\x1a_M)11\xea\x16=#\x95\xe8b\x1d"k\xe9\xcf\xc6\x90\x0b\xe3\x1c?m\x00.\x84]\xbeT\xa0C\x9a\x0b\x8bP1Jr\xf0\x1ch\x10\xa94\x16\xe5@\nR\xd6\xd3\xc2\x80%\x9d\xa1\xbc\xe4v\xbe\xee;\xb3\x1e/\\\xf6\xd42\xe5K\x1d\xc0=2#Cr\r\xee\xbf]\x9b\xe3[}\xbbL\xca\xde_\xfa\x14\xe6\xd6\xb0D\xf6\xc8R,,Y\xa3\x1a\xe7B\x99N\xf6\xb7SH/}4\xa8\xf7\x1f\xd7\x0b\xc8\x9d6\x1cG\xec\xf1\xacd\x8e\xf0\xa6\x01\xaa|\xfet\x00;\xf9\xf0\xa0`\xaf\xf3\xa0\x0ex[\xc6\x98\x8f\xad\xae\x9c)\x001\xa0\xf8\xf2\xa2\x06v\xd7\xa3a\x1d\x00\x01\xa6\x94H$p\x9a\x06\x16\xd7<)\x01\xc5F\xb84\x00\xb3\x18\x7f^!\xfe\xa1\xa5i\xea/\xf5\xa9\xf3EY\xbfC\xf9\x16>.\x1c\x8f\x1a\xc8\x86\xc6\xfc+\xf4\x07_L4\xf9#\xe1\xbd\xca\xbbv.\xff\x00\xeac\xb6\\L1\xd9\xe5}\x00\xe1\xf0\xa82\xfa\xed\xa9\x05\xca*\xe7\xa8\x1f\xcbQh\x95\x1e\xa51\xdc\xc0\xfd\xcbt\xf0\x0ct\xaa-\xa9\xaa\xac\xab\xbb\x81\x1c\xb0k\xd8\xf4\xda\xd5KF\xaa\xb9\xd4\xa3{\x9a_\xf7\x11\xb4(\r\xaa1\x08\xaf#\x96\x91\x9e\xf7\xc9\x1b\xd7\x90\x13q\xad\xab\x89\xdbz\x9e\x8f\xa5_\xa5\x10,\x83v:\xf15\xc4\xc8wq\x80\xc5\xc5\x977+\x1f\x0e\x05-.L\x8b\x1cj<X\xda\xaa\x89-\x92\xce\xf7\x07\x1e\x1cM\xafb\xc5\xc6\xff\x00\xd2\xe3\x07\xc7\x8d\x87\x06h\xec\x18\xfe7\xa8\xdd\xc9dBD;\t\xcc\xbb\x1c\xb0\x9b\x9f\xb5\x9f\xd4\x8dG\xfa\xb8\xd4<\x07\xe0H\xbbkr\x96\xcf\x87$\xbf\xd3\x9b\xa9\x11\x0e\xa0iR\xad\x85\x03.\xf0\xb2\xa8\x05d\x02(\x98\xaa\x81\xc6\xc6\xf75+1A\x18i\x1cH\x18\x1dE\x8f\xe1U\xc8\xc0\xcb3L\xec\xcen\xccnM\r\xc8\x0b\xb6\xad\xb7\'x\xdc0v\xcc4\xeb\xcb\xdc2#\xc7\xc7^?T\x86\xd7\xf9q\xa9c\xa3\xbd\x95V\xed\xc1\x1b\xde\xb4\xab\xb5\xb6Z\x9e\x80c\xf6n\x07j\xf6\xde\xd7\xb0a\x8fV\x1cD\xea\x9eC\xc5\xe5:\xbb\x9f\x89\xbd{\xbe\xbfUu\xe8\xa9_\x0f\xe7\xe2xN\xd7e\xf6n\xee\xfc\x7f\x97\x81\x07\xee\x1d\xb1!\x18\xf1\xf4t\xac\xaaX\x8br\xa5li\x95\xdb#\xac\x15\x16\xe5\xb6\x84|\x87(\x01\x1a\x00|\x05c\xcb\x84\xbf\x17a\xa7\x05y\x9f\x8c\xddLJ\xdb\xa7\x9f\xc6\xb8\xf9\xf1C;\xdd|\xba\x11l\x84\x01\x9b\xc4h+\x9dz\xc1\xd4\xa5\xb4\x100\xaaYr\x01\xc6\x90\xceZ\x806\xbc\xab~\x07C^Y\x1e\x8cB\x82\xd9\x0b\xa7\x8dJ\xa4l\x1b\x94n\x96\xb7:l\x10\xd8\\\x83m~\x14\x86|\xedu$\x9b\x80)\xa2\'\xa4\x1f\xa4/g\xe0\x8b\x01{\xcbv\xc6\x073q!\xf1}E\xd5#\x1c\x00\x07\xc7\x8dz\x9fn\xeb\xfaX\xe5\xfe\xa6r\xfb99\xdb\xe0\x8d\xf9\xb9e\xc5\x89\x12\xe2\xe3\xd9zE\x9a\xdf\xba\xba\x89\x1c\xfb\xd9\xb6Aw\r\xcbB\xa5\xef\xa6\xa6\xf4\x9b"R\x1d\xe9\xdc?e\x14\xad\xd7\xa8\x06\xdeu\x8b\xb1\x92\t\xd2\xb2\xcc=\xeeG\x7f\xfd\x9c9sI)\xea\xb1\xe8\xd6\xb8\xb9\x1b\xbd\x8d\xd5\x8a\xadO?;\xbf\xbew\x1d\xef.`\'a\x0fQ\x1a\x1e>U\xa7\x1e$\x8am\x91\xd8\xae\x99\xd9\x89,I\'\x9d\\V|\x1e\xdf*\x06\x1c\xb3Z\x88\t\x042\xe4\x89\xd6H\x9a\xcf\x19\xea_\x95(\x90\x93\xd1\xefa}\xca\x83\x07\xb3\xb6\xcc\\3\xd7\xbbn.\xc2H\xc1\xb9\x0e\xa4\x83\xfb\xaa\x9cT\xe2\xe1\x17\xbbrRi\x0fm\xf6\x8e\xe9\xf7+\xbfFN\xed+\xa6\xc7\xb5\x10\x90c\x0b\xdaI\x0e\xa5\x8f\xc2\xba\x9djrz\x98rRo\xa9\xe8\xeabA\xdb\xfbd\x18\xd1\x00\xac\xb1\x81\x7f\x95n\x80\xb3\x8d\x11\x05\xce\xdd5f&\xe7\x96\xb4\x9b"\x86w\xde\x18\xa3\xd9\xb8p\xa8\xf2\x19\x04\xdd\xb7\xa6_Q\xaeG\x10Mf\xcbx\'De\xdfp\xfb\xa7\xa6IT\xc8B)$\xdf\x9dq{\x17vf\xdcU\x8dO>\xbd\xd9\xf7\x16\\\x89\xdf\x07\x1ak\x12H!|)a\xc5\x1a\x8b-\xfc\x0c\xd76L\xb2\xbb;1fn$\xf3\xadi\x14HP\x90\xf8\xd3\x00\xf8\xe7e`\xc1\x8a\x957V\x06\xc4\x1aM\r2\xea\xec?};\xa7\xb2\xa6\xc7Ifm\xd3n\x84\x8b\xc2\xecz\xc2\xf9\x1eu\xce\xec{m2\xeb]\x19\xb3\x0fv\xf8\xf4\xdd\x1e\xd6~\x9f=\xd2\xc0\xef\xce\xda\xc0\xdcp\xa6\xeb\xc6\xcc\x88\x14\xea\xe2\xad\xc0\xa9\xf0 \xe8k\xcc\xe6\xc1j6\x9a\xd5\x1e\x8f\xad\x9dd\xac\xa2\xda\xee\x18\xdb5$\x84\x1b\x9f\xc6\xa9\xa5a\x97]\xca\'\x9e\xd3\xfb}\x8b\x89\xd5\xba\xe5\xc2=w7\x1dC\xf0\xafg\xec\xfdh\xa76\xb5g\x9c\xefe\x87\x05\xe1\x9f\x9c\x98\xea`\x82\xca\x17\x8d\xab\xbe\x91\xc7nH\x8ef\xe9\xd0\x8c\xcc\xda\x00i\x82F|\xf7\x0f\xbb}\x18&\x8e9lX\x10\x005\x87\xb1\x93B\xcaT\xc2=\xdd\xdd\x13df\xcb\x1f\xab\xd6U\xb5\x17\xae\x05\xdf&o\xc6\x92D_\x1b%\xde\xcc\xe6\xe4\x9d\r%Rd\x8b\x16F\x1a\x83\xa7\x858\t\x10w\x0edx\x98R\xce\xdc\x94\xb0\x15\xcf\xeda\xe4n\xebe\x83\x03{\xad\xdc\x19\x1b\xdeL\xb8\xf8\xe0\xba\x82A\xb7\xf8\xd6\x9fn\xc2\xb1\xbeL\xcf\xdd\xca\xef\xa2),ll\xa8e^\xa8\x99E\xf8\x91]\x9b\xde\xadns\xabK&[\xbbO[\xe1\xc7\x0cb\xf2L\xcb\x12\x81\xc6\xeezG\xef\xac-\x9aQ\xef\x17\xe9\x8b\xb4!\xd8\xbbGe\xc7XB\xfd\xb6,a\xb4\xb5\xc8]\x7fmuz\x95\x8a#=\x9e\xec\xb7{\xc2G\xea\x90\x83\xe3j\xb6\xe5Fb\xef\x16\x97\xd2\x98\x9b\xfd7\xd6\xb3\\\x9a1\x97{\xeeS$\x92\xa0\xbe\x84\xe8+\x9d\x96\xda\x9aj\x88F\xc0L\xd2\x16o\xccM\xea\x92d\xce\xda\xf9\xd2b$\x18.W\xc4\xf0\xb5E\x8cO\xbe\xe3,\xf0
1 / 1

The log indicates that body_data is of type bytearray, and the content looks like the byte representation of an image file (probably a JPEG file given the starting bytes \xff\xd8\xff).

This means that the image is being received correctly. The issue likely lies in the code where you're trying to process this bytearray.

A common issue is the encoding or decoding step while converting the byte array into an image. In your code, you have:

python
if isinstance(body_data, (bytes, bytearray)):
    image = Image.open(io.BytesIO(body_data))

The Image.open() function from PIL should be able to handle byte arrays without a problem, so the issue might be elsewhere in your code.

Here are a few things to check:

  1. Dependencies: Make sure you have the correct versions of all dependencies, and that PIL (Pillow) is correctly installed.

  2. Data Transformation: After reading the image, make sure that you are correctly transforming it to a tensor or an array before sending it to the model. Debug the shapes and types at each stage to ensure they match what the model expects.

  3. Error Handling: Your code does not have much error handling. You might want to add some try and except blocks to catch and log errors. This can help you understand where the problem lies.

If you could isolate the part of the code that's failing (e.g., reading the image, transforming it, running the model inference), it would be easier to diagnose the issue.

1 / 1
isn't it that this is being evaluated to false? isinstance(body_data, bytes)
1 / 1

If the log is showing that body_data is of type bytearray, then the condition isinstance(body_data, (bytes, bytearray)) should evaluate to True. The isinstance function checks if an object is an instance of a class or a subclass thereof. In this case, you're checking if body_data is an instance of either bytes or bytearray, and according to the logs, it is a bytearray.

So, that part of the code should actually be executing as expected.

If you are suspecting that this line is not being executed, you could add additional logging right inside that if block to confirm:

python
if isinstance(body_data, (bytes, bytearray)):
    logging.info("Inside the byte processing block")
    image = Image.open(io.BytesIO(body_data))

If you don't see the log message "Inside the byte processing block", then the condition is indeed not being met, which would be very strange given that your log says body_data is a bytearray.

1 / 1
changed to this and it works if isinstance(body_data, bytearray):
1 / 1

Great to hear that your issue is resolved!

It seems like explicitly checking for bytearray made the difference. This suggests that for some reason, the Python environment where this code is running is not treating bytearray as a subclass of bytes or that the tuple check (bytes, bytearray) wasn't working as expected.

Either way, if your data is always going to be a bytearray, then checking for it explicitly is a reasonable solution. Keep in mind that this will not work if for some reason the data comes in as bytes instead of bytearray in the future. But given your specific scenario, this seems like a suitable fix.

1 / 1
can we send this now? POST http://localhost:8080/predictions/segment_anything/1.0 Content-Type: application/json { "uid": "03d40666-05c4-4908-9e09-6ee43c6fae5e", "point_coords": [[500, 375]], "point_labels": [1] }
1 / 1

You can send a POST request with the specified JSON payload to your local server, but there are a few things to consider:

  1. Content-Type: Make sure that the server is expecting application/json for the specific endpoint you are hitting.
  2. Endpoint: Confirm that the endpoint (http://localhost:8080/predictions/segment_anything/1.0) is correct and available.
  3. Payload: Ensure that the server is expecting the JSON keys (uid, point_coords, point_labels) and that their types match what is expected (e.g., string for uid, list of lists for point_coords, etc.).
  4. Authentication: If your API requires authentication, make sure you include the necessary headers or tokens.
  5. Method: Since it's a POST request, ensure that the server accepts POST requests at this endpoint.

You can use various tools to send HTTP requests, like Postman, or you can use command-line tools like curl. You can also use Python libraries such as requests to send this POST request programmatically.

Here's how you could do it using curl from the command line:

bash
curl --header "Content-Type: application/json" \
  --request POST \
  --data '{"uid":"03d40666-05c4-4908-9e09-6ee43c6fae5e","point_coords":[[500, 375]],"point_labels":[1]}' \
  http://localhost:8080/predictions/segment_anything/1.0

And here's how you could do it using Python's requests library:

python
import requests
import json

url = "http://localhost:8080/predictions/segment_anything/1.0"
headers = {'Content-Type': 'application/json'}

payload = {
  "uid": "03d40666-05c4-4908-9e09-6ee43c6fae5e",
  "point_coords": [[500, 375]],
  "point_labels": [1]
}

response = requests.post(url, headers=headers, data=json.dumps(payload))

print(response.text)

Remember, you'll need to install the requests library if you haven't done so already. You can install it using pip:

bash
pip install requests

Note: Please replace the URL, headers, and payload as per your specific requirements.

1 / 1
We get this: 2023-09-06T16:24:59,631 [INFO ] W-9002-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - Invoking custom service failed. 2023-09-06T16:24:59,631 [INFO ] W-9002-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - Traceback (most recent call last): 2023-09-06T16:24:59,631 [INFO ] W-9002-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - File "/Users/lapuerta/dev/tserve/env/lib/python3.11/site-packages/ts/service.py", line 134, in predict 2023-09-06T16:24:59,631 [INFO ] W-9002-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - ret = self._entry_point(input_batch, self.context) 2023-09-06T16:24:59,632 [INFO ] W-9002-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ 2023-09-06T16:24:59,634 [INFO ] W-9002-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - File "/Users/lapuerta/dev/tserve/env/lib/python3.11/site-packages/ts/torch_handler/base_handler.py", line 355, in handle 2023-09-06T16:24:59,634 [INFO ] W-9002-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - data_preprocess = self.preprocess(data) 2023-09-06T16:24:59,634 [INFO ] W-9002-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ 2023-09-06T16:24:59,634 [INFO ] W-9002-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - File "/private/var/folders/3x/wb42gyq95ts03_70yq2vdc_h0000gn/T/models/c20b41caa4b44fd1a514430c6cea353e/new_handler.py", line 66, in preprocess 2023-09-06T16:24:59,634 [INFO ] W-9002-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - self.retrieve_and_set_embedding(uid) 2023-09-06T16:24:59,634 [INFO ] W-9002-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - File "/private/var/folders/3x/wb42gyq95ts03_70yq2vdc_h0000gn/T/models/c20b41caa4b44fd1a514430c6cea353e/new_handler.py", line 26, in retrieve_and_set_embedding 2023-09-06T16:24:59,634 [INFO ] W-9002-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - raise ValueError(f"No embedding found for UID {uid}") 2023-09-06T16:24:59,634 [INFO ] W-9002-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - ValueError: No embedding found for UID ae9a1417-f5ea-4965-8232-0fce03aabc83 and I think I know why, can you guess?
1 / 1

The log indicates that the error is related to the UID value specified in the request, specifically this line:

plaintext
ValueError: No embedding found for UID ae9a1417-f5ea-4965-8232-0fce03aabc83

The server is expecting to find an embedding associated with the provided UID, but it appears that there is none available for the UID "ae9a1417-f5ea-4965-8232-0fce03aabc83".

Possible reasons for this issue could be:

  1. UID Mismatch: The UID you sent in the POST request ("03d40666-05c4-4908-9e09-6ee43c6fae5e") is different from the one mentioned in the error ("ae9a1417-f5ea-4965-8232-0fce03aabc83"). Make sure you are using the correct UID.

  2. Database/Storage Issue: If the server is expected to look up this UID in a database or some other form of storage, then perhaps the UID is not available or not populated correctly.

  3. Timing Issues: If the embeddings are generated asynchronously or in a separate process, it's possible that the embedding for this UID has not been generated yet at the time of the request.

  4. Caching Issues: If the embeddings are stored in some cache, it might have been evicted or not yet populated.

  5. Server-Side Logic: There might be some issue in the server-side logic that retrieves the embeddings. This would require debugging the server code.

If you have control over the server, you may want to check the mechanism that is supposed to associate UIDs with embeddings to understand why it failed in this case.

1 / 1
torchserve by default starts 8 workers. I don't think uid_embedding_map is shared between them, do you?
1 / 1

You're correct. In multi-worker deployments like TorchServe with multiple worker processes, each worker process runs in its own Python interpreter and has its own memory space. Therefore, any global variables like uid_embedding_map would not be shared between different workers.

If you need to share data like embeddings across multiple workers, you have several options:

  1. Database: Use a database to store and retrieve the embeddings. Each worker can query the database to get the necessary data.

  2. Shared Cache: Use a distributed cache like Redis to hold the embeddings. Workers can then read from and write to this cache.

  3. Inter-Process Communication (IPC): Use some form of IPC to share data between processes, though this might be complex to set up and manage.

  4. File-Based: You could also store embeddings in a shared file system that all workers can read from, though this could lead to I/O bottlenecks.

  5. Singleton Service: Create a separate microservice whose sole responsibility is to manage embeddings. All TorchServe workers can then query this service.

  6. Stateless Design: If possible, design your application to be stateless, so that each request contains all the information needed to process it. This is the most scalable and fault-tolerant approach, but it may not be applicable to all types of problems.

It's generally best to use an external storage or service for sharing state in a scalable, multi-worker deployment.

1 / 1
redis sounds pretty perfect for this no?
1 / 1

Yes, Redis is often a great fit for scenarios like this. It's a fast, in-memory data store that supports data structures such as strings, hashes, lists, sets, and more. Redis is widely used for caching and sharing data between multiple processes or services. Here are some reasons why Redis might be suitable for your use case:

Advantages:

  1. Speed: Redis is in-memory and optimized for high-performance, making it much faster than disk-based databases.

  2. Concurrency: Multiple workers can read from and write to Redis simultaneously.

  3. Atomic Operations: Redis supports complex atomic operations on these data types.

  4. Persistence: You can configure it to save data to disk without losing much performance.

  5. Networked: Redis can be accessed by multiple services across different servers, which is useful for distributed systems.

  6. Community and Ecosystem: Redis has a large community and a lot of client libraries, making it easy to use with various programming languages.

  7. Simple to Use: Its simplicity and straightforward API can allow for quick prototyping.

Potential Downsides:

  1. Memory Usage: Being an in-memory database, Redis could be expensive if you're storing a large amount of data. However, you can configure it for your needs and use disk-based storage as a fallback.

  2. Single-threaded Model: CPU-bound tasks can be a bottleneck, but this is usually not a problem for I/O-bound use cases like caching.

  3. Data Loss: In a pure in-memory setting without persistence, you risk data loss in case of a system failure. However, Redis does offer various persistence options.

To get started, you'd install Redis, start the Redis server, and then use a Python Redis client like redis-py to interact with the Redis server from your TorchServe custom handler. You'd use Redis to set and get the embeddings by UID.

1 / 1
GPT! It's time to write the redis layer, I hope you are PUMPED! We need to do this really good so, please focus. High level, how should we implement this?
1 / 1

I'm definitely excited to help you implement the Redis layer! Here's a high-level outline of what the implementation might look like:

High-Level Design

  1. Initialization:

    • Initialize a Redis client when the TorchServe custom handler starts.
    • The client should connect to the Redis server running either locally or in a remote setup.

  2. UID-Embedding Mapping:

    • Use Redis hashes or key-value pairs to store the mapping between UID and the corresponding embedding.
    • Hashes are more memory-efficient and allow for more complex data structures.

  3. Data Ingestion:

    • When a new image comes in and the embedding is generated, push this data to Redis using the UID as the key.
    • You can set an expiration time for the data if needed.

  4. Data Retrieval:

    • When a prediction request comes in, first check if the UID exists in Redis.
    • If it does, retrieve the embedding and use it for prediction.

  5. Error Handling:

    • Handle cases where the Redis server is down or unreachable.
    • Handle cases where a UID does not exist in the cache.

  6. Logging and Monitoring:

    • Log important events like cache hits and misses, data insertion, and deletion.
    • Optionally, monitor the performance and health of the Redis server.

  7. Cleanup and Maintenance (Optional):

    • Periodically remove stale or unused data.
    • Use Redis persistence features to backup data.

  8. Scalability (If Required):

    • If your application scales horizontally, ensure that all instances connect to the same Redis server or cluster.

  9. Testing:

    • Write unit tests to ensure that the Redis layer works as expected.

Technologies and Libraries

  • Redis Server: The actual database that will run either locally or on a cloud provider.
  • Redis-py: Python client for Redis.
  • TorchServe Custom Handler: Where you'll integrate the Redis client.

Pseudocode

Here's some very basic pseudocode to demonstrate points 2-4:

python
# Initialization
redis_client = redis.Redis(host='localhost', port=6379, db=0)

# Data Ingestion
def store_embedding(uid, embedding):
    redis_client.hset("uid_embedding_map", uid, embedding)

# Data Retrieval
def retrieve_embedding(uid):
    return redis_client.hget("uid_embedding_map", uid)

# Inside TorchServe Custom Handler
def preprocess(data):
    uid = data['uid']
    embedding = retrieve_embedding(uid)
    if embedding is None:
        raise ValueError(f"No embedding found for UID {uid}")
    # Continue with preprocessing

Are you ready to dive into the code?

1 / 1
yeah, first of all, do we need to have a redis instance running somewhere locally, and then do we connect to it inside handler?
1 / 1

Yes, you'll need a Redis instance running either locally or on a remote server. You can then connect to it using the Python Redis client within your TorchServe custom handler. Here's how you can set up both:

Setting up a Redis Instance Locally

  1. Docker Method: If you have Docker installed, you can run a Redis instance by using the following command:

    bash
    docker run --name redis-server -p 6379:6379 -d redis

  2. Manual Installation:

    • Download and install Redis from the official website.
    • Start the Redis server by running redis-server.

Connecting to Redis in TorchServe Custom Handler

You can initialize a Redis client when your TorchServe custom handler starts up. The Redis client will then connect to the Redis server running on the specified host and port. Here's a code snippet for the initialization:

python
import redis

class MyHandler:
    def __init__(self):
        self.redis_client = redis.Redis(host='localhost', port=6379, db=0)

    def preprocess(self, data):
        uid = data['uid']
        embedding = self.retrieve_embedding(uid)
        if embedding is None:
            raise ValueError(f"No embedding found for UID {uid}")
        # Continue with preprocessing

    def retrieve_embedding(self, uid):
        return self.redis_client.hget("uid_embedding_map", uid)

    def store_embedding(self, uid, embedding):
        self.redis_client.hset("uid_embedding_map", uid, embedding)

In this example, I used the Redis hset and hget methods to store and retrieve data in a Redis hash. The hash is named "uid_embedding_map", and it contains key-value pairs where the key is the uid and the value is the embedding.

By doing this, you're connecting to the Redis server each time the TorchServe handler is initialized, and you can then use the Redis client to store or retrieve data as needed.

1 / 1
do i need to pip install redis?
1 / 1

Yes, you'll need to install the Redis Python client library. Typically, this is done using pip:

bash
pip install redis

You can add this to your requirements.txt file for your custom handler, so that it gets installed automatically when your model is deployed on TorchServe.

1 / 1
should I not used this fn: def initialize(self, context): logger.info("Initializing...") model_type = "vit_b" model_dir = context.system_properties.get("model_dir") self.sam = sam_model_registry[model_type](checkpoint=f"{model_dir}/vit_b.pth") self.sam.eval() self.predictor = SamPredictor(self.sam) self.initialized = True logger.info("Initialization complete.") instead of the __init__?
1 / 1

The initialize function and the __init__ constructor serve different purposes in the TorchServe custom handler.

  • The __init__ constructor is called when the class is instantiated. This method is generally used for general object initialization that does not require access to the model artifacts or other runtime-specific information.

  • The initialize function, on the other hand, is specifically designed to handle initialization tasks that require access to model artifacts or other system properties. This function is called by TorchServe when the model is loaded.

So, if you want to initialize the Redis connection and you need to access model-specific or system-specific information (like model_dir), then initialize would be the appropriate place to do it. If the Redis initialization doesn't require such information, you could do it in __init__.

For your Redis layer, you could initialize the Redis client in either the __init__ or initialize method, depending on your specific needs. If all you need is to connect to a Redis server and this doesn't depend on any model-specific information, doing it in __init__ should suffice.

1 / 1
alright, what can i log after we have connected to redis to show success?
1 / 1

After successfully connecting to Redis, you can log various messages to indicate that the connection was successful. Here are some suggestions:

  1. A simple success message:

    python
    logger.info("Successfully connected to Redis.")

  2. Redis Server Information: You can run the Redis INFO command to get server information and log some of it.

    python
    info = redis_client.info()
logger.info(f"Connected to Redis server: {info['server']['redis_version']}")

  3. Ping the Redis server: You can use the PING command to check if the server is responsive.

    python
    pong = redis_client.ping()
logger.info(f"Redis PING returned: {pong}")

  4. Current database size: You can use the dbsize command to log the number of keys in the current database.

    python
    db_size = redis_client.dbsize()
logger.info(f"Current Redis database size: {db_size} keys")

Choose the one that best fits your needs, or you can even log multiple of these for more detailed information.

1 / 1
alright, so what do we have to change now: class SAMHandler(BaseHandler): def __init__(self): self.redis_client = redis.Redis(host="localhost", port=6379, db=0) logger.info("Successfully connected to Redis.") def generate_and_save_uid(self, image): # set embedding in redis uid = str(uuid.uuid4()) if self.predictor.features is not None: self.uid_embedding_map[uid] = self.predictor.features.clone() logger.info(f"all keys (uids): {self.uid_embedding_map.keys()}") return uid def retrieve_and_set_embedding(self, uid): # get embedding from redis embedding = self.uid_embedding_map.get(uid, None) if embedding is None: logger.info(f"all keys (uids): {self.uid_embedding_map.keys()}") raise ValueError(f"No embedding found for UID {uid}") self.predictor.features = embedding def initialize(self, context): logger.info("Initializing...") model_type = "vit_b" model_dir = context.system_properties.get("model_dir") self.sam = sam_model_registry[model_type](checkpoint=f"{model_dir}/vit_b.pth") self.sam.eval() self.predictor = SamPredictor(self.sam) self.initialized = True logger.info("Initialization complete.") def preprocess(self, data): logger.info("Preprocessing...") request_data = data[0] body_data = request_data.get("body") if isinstance(body_data, bytearray): # It's an embedding request logging.info("Inside the byte processing block") image_data = BytesIO(body_data) image = Image.open(image_data).convert("RGB") image = np.array(image) self.predictor.set_image(image) uid = self.generate_and_save_uid(image) return uid, None, "embedding" elif isinstance(body_data, dict) and "uid" in body_data: # It's a prediction request uid = body_data.get("uid") point_coords = np.array(body_data.get("point_coords", [[500, 375]])) point_labels = np.array(body_data.get("point_labels", [1])) self.retrieve_and_set_embedding(uid) return point_coords, point_labels, "prediction" else: raise ValueError("Invalid request payload") def inference(self, model_input): logger.info("Running inference...") job_type = model_input[2] if job_type == "prediction": point_coords, point_labels = model_input[:2] masks, scores, logits = self.predictor.predict( point_coords=point_coords, point_labels=point_labels, multimask_output=True, ) logger.info("Inference complete.") return masks, scores, logits, "prediction" else: return model_input[0], None, None, "embedding" def postprocess(self, inference_output): logger.info("Postprocessing...") if inference_output[3] == "prediction": masks, scores, logits = inference_output[:3] logger.info(f"Postprocessing complete") return [[masks.tolist(), logits.tolist(), scores.tolist()]] else: uid = inference_output[0] logger.info(f"Postprocessing complete") return [[uid]]
1 / 1

To integrate Redis into your SAMHandler class, you'll need to make the following changes:

  1. Initialization: Initialize the Redis client in the initialize method instead of __init__.
  2. Save UID and Embedding: Use Redis commands to set the UID and its corresponding embedding.
  3. Retrieve Embedding: Use Redis commands to get the embedding based on the UID.

Here's how you can update the class:

python
import redis

class SAMHandler(BaseHandler):
    def initialize(self, context):
        logger.info("Initializing...")
        self.redis_client = redis.Redis(host="localhost", port=6379, db=0)
        pong = self.redis_client.ping()
        logger.info(f"Redis PING returned: {pong}")

        model_type = "vit_b"
        model_dir = context.system_properties.get("model_dir")
        self.sam = sam_model_registry[model_type](checkpoint=f"{model_dir}/vit_b.pth")
        self.sam.eval()
        self.predictor = SamPredictor(self.sam)
        self.initialized = True
        logger.info("Initialization complete.")

    def generate_and_save_uid(self, image):
        uid = str(uuid.uuid4())
        if self.predictor.features is not None:
            embedding = self.predictor.features.clone().cpu().numpy().tobytes()
            self.redis_client.set(uid, embedding)
            logger.info(f"Saved embedding for UID: {uid}")
        return uid

    def retrieve_and_set_embedding(self, uid):
        embedding_bytes = self.redis_client.get(uid)
        if embedding_bytes is None:
            raise ValueError(f"No embedding found for UID {uid}")
        
        embedding = torch.from_numpy(np.frombuffer(embedding_bytes, dtype=np.float32)).to(self.sam.device)
        self.predictor.features = embedding

    # ... (rest of your code remains unchanged)

Key Changes:

  • I moved the Redis client initialization to the initialize method, as per best practices.
  • I used redis_client.set and redis_client.get to interact with Redis for saving and retrieving embeddings.
  • To save space and improve performance, I'm saving the tensor as a byte array (numpy().tobytes()). Note that this assumes that you'll be saving and loading the tensor using the same dtype and shape.

Now, your handler should be able to use Redis to share embeddings between different workers.

1 / 1
I modified your code to this: import uuid from io import BytesIO from PIL import Image import logging import numpy as np import torch import redis from ts.torch_handler.base_handler import BaseHandler from segment_anything import sam_model_registry, SamPredictor logger = logging.getLogger(__name__) class SAMHandler(BaseHandler): def initialize(self, context): logger.info("Initializing...") self.redis_client = redis.Redis(host="localhost", port=6379, db=0) pong = self.redis_client.ping() logger.info(f"Redis PING returned: {pong}") model_type = "vit_b" model_dir = context.system_properties.get("model_dir") self.sam = sam_model_registry[model_type](checkpoint=f"{model_dir}/vit_b.pth") self.sam.eval() self.predictor = SamPredictor(self.sam) self.initialized = True logger.info("Initialization complete.") def set_embedding(self, image): self.predictor.set_image(image) uid = str(uuid.uuid4()) if self.predictor.features is not None: embedding = self.predictor.features.clone().cpu().numpy().tobytes() self.redis_client.set(uid, embedding) logger.info(f"Saved embedding for UID: {uid}") return uid def get_embedding(self, uid): embedding_bytes = self.redis_client.get(uid) if embedding_bytes is None: raise ValueError(f"No embedding found for UID {uid}") return torch.from_numpy(np.frombuffer(embedding_bytes, dtype=np.float32)).to(self.sam.device) def preprocess(self, data): logger.info("Preprocessing...") request_data = data[0] body_data = request_data.get("body") if isinstance(body_data, bytearray): # It's an embedding request logging.info("Inside the byte processing block") image_data = BytesIO(body_data) image = Image.open(image_data).convert("RGB") image = np.array(image) uid = self.set_embedding(image) return uid, None, "embedding" elif isinstance(body_data, dict) and "uid" in body_data: # It's a prediction request uid = body_data.get("uid") point_coords = np.array(body_data.get("point_coords", [[500, 375]])) point_labels = np.array(body_data.get("point_labels", [1])) embedding = self.get_embedding(uid) self.predictor.features = embedding return point_coords, point_labels, "prediction" else: raise ValueError("Invalid request payload") def inference(self, model_input): logger.info("Running inference...") job_type = model_input[2] if job_type == "prediction": point_coords, point_labels = model_input[:2] masks, scores, logits = self.predictor.predict( point_coords=point_coords, point_labels=point_labels, multimask_output=True, ) logger.info("Inference complete.") return masks, scores, logits, "prediction" else: return model_input[0], None, None, "embedding" def postprocess(self, inference_output): logger.info("Postprocessing...") if inference_output[3] == "prediction": masks, scores, logits = inference_output[:3] logger.info(f"Postprocessing complete") return [[masks.tolist(), logits.tolist(), scores.tolist()]] else: uid = inference_output[0] logger.info(f"Postprocessing complete") return [[uid]]
1 / 1

Your modified code looks good! You've abstracted the Redis interaction into separate set_embedding and get_embedding methods, which makes the code clean and easy to follow.

Here's a quick summary of what you've done:

  1. You've moved the initialization of the Redis client to the initialize method.
  2. You've created set_embedding and get_embedding methods for saving and retrieving embeddings in Redis, respectively.
  3. In preprocess, you're calling these new methods to either save a new embedding or retrieve an existing one based on the UID.

This should effectively enable your TorchServe model to share embeddings across different workers using Redis as a centralized cache.

Just a couple of things to keep in mind:

  1. Expiration: If you're dealing with a large number of embeddings, you might want to set an expiration time for each key to avoid filling up your Redis instance. You can do this by using the EX parameter in self.redis_client.set() method.

    python
    self.redis_client.set(uid, embedding, ex=3600)  # expires in 1 hour

  2. Error Handling: Currently, you're raising a ValueError if the embedding is not found in Redis. Depending on your application, you might want to handle this more gracefully, perhaps by returning a specific error message to the client or falling back to a default behavior.

Other than these considerations, your implementation looks solid!

1 / 1
if we look closely here, what are we storing redis? what data type? def set_embedding(self, image): self.predictor.set_image(image) uid = str(uuid.uuid4()) if self.predictor.features is not None: embedding = self.predictor.features.clone().cpu().numpy().tobytes() self.redis_client.set(uid, embedding) logger.info(f"Saved embedding for UID: {uid}") return uid
1 / 1

In the set_embedding method, you are storing the embedding as bytes. Specifically, you're doing the following conversions:

  1. First, you clone the tensor and move it to CPU: self.predictor.features.clone().cpu().
  2. Then you convert the PyTorch tensor to a NumPy array: .numpy().
  3. Finally, you convert the NumPy array to bytes: .tobytes().

So in Redis, the embedding is stored as a bytes object, associated with the UID as the key. This is a practical approach for storing large numerical arrays efficiently.

1 / 1
alright cool. after running: docker run --name redis-server -p 6379:6379 -d redis in the terminal, can I connect to it somehow and run commands?
1 / 1

Yes, you can connect to the running Redis instance and execute Redis commands interactively using the Redis CLI (Command Line Interface). The Redis CLI allows you to execute all sorts of Redis commands right from your terminal.

Here's how you can do it:

  1. Connect to the running Redis container: To do this, you'll need to open a new terminal window and run the following command to get an interactive shell inside the running Redis container:

    bash
    docker exec -it redis-server redis-cli

    This command does the following:

    • docker exec -it: Runs a command in a running container.
    • redis-server: Name of the running Redis container.
    • redis-cli: The command to start the Redis CLI.

  2. Execute Redis Commands: Once connected, you can start typing Redis commands. For example, you can run:

    bash
    keys *

    This will show you all the keys in the Redis database. Or you can get/set values like this:

    bash
    get some_key
set some_key some_value

  3. Exit: You can exit the Redis CLI by typing exit.

This will allow you to interact with your Redis instance and run commands, inspect data, etc.

1 / 1
what are some commands I can run?
1 / 1

Certainly! Here are some commonly used Redis commands:

Key-Value Operations

  1. SET: Sets the value of a key.

    bash
    SET key value

  2. GET: Retrieves the value of a key.

    bash
    GET key

  3. DEL: Deletes a key.

    bash
    DEL key

  4. EXISTS: Checks if a key exists.

    bash
    EXISTS key

  5. KEYS: Lists all keys matching a pattern.

    bash
    KEYS pattern

List Operations

  1. LPUSH: Adds one or more elements to the head of a list.

    bash
    LPUSH key value1 value2 ...

  2. RPUSH: Adds one or more elements to the tail of a list.

    bash
    RPUSH key value1 value2 ...

  3. LPOP: Removes and returns the first element of a list.

    bash
    LPOP key

  4. RPOP: Removes and returns the last element of a list.

    bash
    RPOP key

Set Operations

  1. SADD: Adds one or more members to a set.

    bash
    SADD key member1 member2 ...

  2. SMEMBERS: Lists all members of a set.

    bash
    SMEMBERS key

  3. SISMEMBER: Checks if a member exists in a set.

    bash
    SISMEMBER key member

Hash Operations

  1. HSET: Sets the value of a field in a hash.

    bash
    HSET key field value

  2. HGET: Retrieves the value of a field in a hash.

    bash
    HGET key field

  3. HDEL: Deletes a field from a hash.

    bash
    HDEL key field

General Commands

  1. PING: Checks if the server is running.

    bash
    PING

  2. INFO: Provides various information and statistics about the server.

    bash
    INFO

  3. FLUSHALL: Removes all keys from all databases.

    bash
    FLUSHALL

  4. DBSIZE: Returns the number of keys in the selected database.

    bash
    DBSIZE

  5. TTL: Gets the time-to-live for a key.

    bash
    TTL key

These are just some basic commands to get you started. Redis supports a wide range of commands for various data structures and use-cases.

1 / 1
aight, tested this now: curl -X POST "http://localhost:8080/predictions/segment_anything/1.0" -T "../images/dog.jpg" and we got: [ "3a4aa58a-859d-485a-92a5-15e2c2d8dc33" ] back
1 / 1

Great, that looks like a successful operation! You sent an image for embedding generation and got a unique identifier (UID) "3a4aa58a-859d-485a-92a5-15e2c2d8dc33" back. This UID should correspond to the image embedding that was saved in Redis. You can use this UID for subsequent prediction requests.

Would you like to proceed with the next steps, such as testing the prediction endpoint using this UID?

1 / 1
can I check if it's in redis?
1 / 1

Yes, you can check if the data corresponding to the UID is stored in Redis. Since you're running Redis in a Docker container, you can connect to the Redis CLI (Command Line Interface) within the container to execute Redis commands.

Here are the steps to check the data in Redis:

  1. Find the Container ID or Name: You can list all running Docker containers by running docker ps in your terminal.

  2. Connect to the Redis CLI: Once you've identified the container ID or name, run the following command to enter the Redis CLI:

    bash
    docker exec -it [Container-ID or Container-Name] redis-cli

  3. Retrieve Data: In the Redis CLI, you can then use the GET command to retrieve the data corresponding to the UID:

    bash
    GET 3a4aa58a-859d-485a-92a5-15e2c2d8dc33

    This should return the stored embedding if it exists.

Would you like to try this and see if the embedding has been successfully stored?

1 / 1
i get (nil) back
1 / 1

If you're getting (nil) back, it could mean one of the following:

  1. Data Expiry: If you've set a time-to-live (TTL) on the Redis key, it might have expired, although this is less likely if you've just set it.

  2. Incorrect Key: Ensure that the key you're using in the Redis CLI matches exactly with the UID returned by your application. Double-check for any typos or extra spaces.

  3. Data Wasn't Set: The data may not have been set in Redis in the first place. Check your application logs to see if there are any errors or exceptions that might have prevented the data from being stored.

  4. Different Database: Redis supports multiple databases, and it's possible that the data is stored in a different database than the one you're checking. Make sure you're connected to the correct database. The default is db=0.

  5. Redis Instance: Ensure that your application and Redis CLI are connected to the same Redis instance.

Would you like to troubleshoot this step-by-step?

1 / 1
sure, these are the logs: 2023-09-06T18:23:18,755 [INFO ] W-9007-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - Redis PING returned: True 2023-09-06T18:23:19,071 [INFO ] W-9003-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - Initialization complete. 2023-09-06T18:23:19,097 [INFO ] W-9006-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - Initialization complete. 2023-09-06T18:23:19,181 [INFO ] W-9001-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - Initialization complete. 2023-09-06T18:23:19,311 [INFO ] W-9004-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - Initialization complete. 2023-09-06T18:23:19,684 [INFO ] W-9002-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - Initialization complete. 2023-09-06T18:23:19,688 [INFO ] W-9005-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - Initialization complete. 2023-09-06T18:23:19,708 [INFO ] W-9000-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - Initialization complete. 2023-09-06T18:23:19,709 [INFO ] W-9007-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - Initialization complete. 2023-09-06T18:23:47,045 [INFO ] W-9003-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - Backend received inference at: 1694017427 2023-09-06T18:23:47,045 [INFO ] W-9003-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - Preprocessing... 2023-09-06T18:23:47,046 [INFO ] W-9003-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - Inside the byte processing block 2023-09-06T18:23:50,830 [INFO ] W-9003-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - Saved embedding for UID: 3a4aa58a-859d-485a-92a5-15e2c2d8dc33 2023-09-06T18:23:50,830 [INFO ] W-9003-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - Running inference... 2023-09-06T18:23:50,830 [INFO ] W-9003-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - Postprocessing... 2023-09-06T18:23:50,830 [INFO ] W-9003-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - Postprocessing complete
1 / 1

The logs indicate that the embedding was successfully saved for the UID 3a4aa58a-859d-485a-92a5-15e2c2d8dc33. It's interesting that you got a (nil) when you tried to retrieve it from Redis.

Here are some steps to troubleshoot:

  1. Double-Check Key: Make sure you typed the UID correctly when trying to retrieve it from Redis.

  2. Redis CLI: Make sure you're connected to the correct Redis instance and database in the CLI. Since you specified db=0 in your code, you should be connected to the same in the CLI.

  3. Multiple Workers: It's possible that the worker that set the data in Redis is not the same as the one you're connected to in the CLI, although that's unlikely because Redis should be a shared resource. It's worth checking if each worker is indeed connected to the same Redis instance and database.

  4. Directly Inspect Redis: You can use Redis commands to directly inspect what keys are currently in the database. Use keys * command in Redis CLI to display all keys in the current database. Note: Be cautious when using keys * on large production databases as it can be resource-intensive.

Try these steps and let's see what we find.

1 / 1
I get (empty array) from doing keys *
1 / 1

If running keys * in the Redis CLI returns an empty array, it means that no keys are currently stored in the database you're connected to. This is puzzling given that your TorchServe logs suggest that the embedding was successfully saved with a specific UID.

Here are some additional things to consider:

  1. Database Selection: Make sure you're checking the correct Redis database. By default, Redis has 16 databases (numbered from 0 to 15). Your application is using db=0, so make sure that's the database you're interacting with in the Redis CLI. You can switch databases in the Redis CLI using the select command (e.g., select 0).

  2. Data Expiry: It's theoretically possible that the data could have an expiry time set, although your code doesn't seem to do that. You can check default expiry settings in Redis.

  3. Redis Server Logs: Check the logs for the Redis server to see if there are any indications of issues like disconnections, errors, or evictions.

  4. Check Connection in TorchServe: Double-check that your TorchServe worker is indeed connected to the Redis server you're checking. They should have the same host and port.

  5. Concurrent Writes: If you have multiple instances of your application writing to Redis, it's possible that one instance could be overwriting or deleting keys set by another.

  6. TorchServe Configuration: Make sure TorchServe is properly configured to keep the workers alive, so they don't terminate and potentially clear the Redis database unintentionally.

  7. Directly Test Redis: As a sanity check, you could also directly set and get a key-value pair in Redis via the CLI to make sure it's working as expected.

  8. Restart Redis: If everything else fails and you're in a safe environment to do so, try restarting the Redis service.

  9. TorchServe to Redis Communication: You can add more logging around the Redis set and get operations in your TorchServe handler to make sure they are completing successfully.

1 / 1
let's try number 9
1 / 1

Sure, adding more logging around the Redis set and get operations will help you debug whether the data is actually being saved and retrieved as expected. Here's how you can modify your SAMHandler class to include additional logs:

python
class SAMHandler(BaseHandler):
    # ... (other methods unchanged)

    def set_embedding(self, image):
        self.predictor.set_image(image)
        uid = str(uuid.uuid4())
        if self.predictor.features is not None:
            embedding = self.predictor.features.clone().cpu().numpy().tobytes()
            set_result = self.redis_client.set(uid, embedding)
            logger.info(f"Redis SET operation result: {set_result}")
            logger.info(f"Saved embedding for UID: {uid}")
        return uid

    def get_embedding(self, uid):
        embedding_bytes = self.redis_client.get(uid)
        if embedding_bytes is None:
            logger.info(f"Redis GET operation returned None for UID: {uid}")
            raise ValueError(f"No embedding found for UID {uid}")
        logger.info(f"Successfully retrieved embedding for UID: {uid}")
        return torch.from_numpy(np.frombuffer(embedding_bytes, dtype=np.float32)).to(self.sam.device)

    # ... (other methods unchanged)

By doing this, you'll get a log entry indicating the result of the Redis set operation, as well as whether or not the get operation was successful.

After making these changes, you can run your TorchServe model again and observe the logs for these new entries.

1 / 1
logs: 2023-09-06T18:33:30,901 [INFO ] W-9004-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - Initialization complete. 2023-09-06T18:34:34,634 [INFO ] W-9007-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - Backend received inference at: 1694018074 2023-09-06T18:34:34,634 [INFO ] W-9007-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - Preprocessing... 2023-09-06T18:34:34,635 [INFO ] W-9007-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - Inside the byte processing block 2023-09-06T18:34:38,683 [INFO ] W-9007-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - Redis SET operation result: True 2023-09-06T18:34:38,684 [INFO ] W-9007-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - Saved embedding for UID: 827d4e05-185f-4738-9b6f-ff56c07cba9a 2023-09-06T18:34:38,684 [INFO ] W-9007-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - Running inference... 2023-09-06T18:34:38,684 [INFO ] W-9007-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - Postprocessing... 2023-09-06T18:34:38,684 [INFO ] W-9007-segment_anything_1.0-stdout MODEL_LOG - Postprocessing complete
1 / 1

The logs indicate that the Redis SET operation was successful (Redis SET operation result: True). This suggests that the embedding should have been saved in Redis under the UID 827d4e05-185f-4738-9b6f-ff56c07cba9a.

If you're still not able to see this UID when running keys * in the Redis CLI, there are a few things you could check:

  1. Connection: Make sure that the Redis instance you are connected to via the CLI is the same as the one your code is connected to.

  2. Expiration: By default, keys in Redis do not expire. However, if you've set an expiration time (TTL), the key might have been removed. You didn't set an expiration in your code, but it's something to keep in mind.

  3. DB Selection: Redis supports multiple databases (usually 16 by default, numbered 0 through 15). Make sure you're checking the right database. Your code uses db=0, so you should be in the same database when checking via CLI.

  4. Check Directly: You can directly check for the existence of the key by running get 827d4e05-185f-4738-9b6f-ff56c07cba9a in the Redis CLI.

Try these steps and let's see if we can identify the issue.

1 / 1
lets take redis to aside a bit, I think we need to customize the SamPredictor a bit: # Copyright (c) Meta Platforms, Inc. and affiliates. # All rights reserved. # This source code is licensed under the license found in the # LICENSE file in the root directory of this source tree. import numpy as np import torch from segment_anything.modeling import Sam from typing import Optional, Tuple from segment_anything.utils.transforms import ResizeLongestSide class SamPredictor: def __init__( self, sam_model: Sam, ) -> None: """ Uses SAM to calculate the image embedding for an image, and then allow repeated, efficient mask prediction given prompts. Arguments: sam_model (Sam): The model to use for mask prediction. """ super().__init__() self.model = sam_model self.transform = ResizeLongestSide(sam_model.image_encoder.img_size) self.reset_image() def set_image( self, image: np.ndarray, image_format: str = "RGB", ) -> None: """ Calculates the image embeddings for the provided image, allowing masks to be predicted with the 'predict' method. Arguments: image (np.ndarray): The image for calculating masks. Expects an image in HWC uint8 format, with pixel values in [0, 255]. image_format (str): The color format of the image, in ['RGB', 'BGR']. """ assert image_format in [ "RGB", "BGR", ], f"image_format must be in ['RGB', 'BGR'], is {image_format}." if image_format != self.model.image_format: image = image[..., ::-1] # Transform the image to the form expected by the model input_image = self.transform.apply_image(image) input_image_torch = torch.as_tensor(input_image, device=self.device) input_image_torch = input_image_torch.permute(2, 0, 1).contiguous()[ None, :, :, : ] self.set_torch_image(input_image_torch, image.shape[:2]) @torch.no_grad() def set_torch_image( self, transformed_image: torch.Tensor, original_image_size: Tuple[int, ...], ) -> None: """ Calculates the image embeddings for the provided image, allowing masks to be predicted with the 'predict' method. Expects the input image to be already transformed to the format expected by the model. Arguments: transformed_image (torch.Tensor): The input image, with shape 1x3xHxW, which has been transformed with ResizeLongestSide. original_image_size (tuple(int, int)): The size of the image before transformation, in (H, W) format. """ assert ( len(transformed_image.shape) == 4 and transformed_image.shape[1] == 3 and max(*transformed_image.shape[2:]) == self.model.image_encoder.img_size ), f"set_torch_image input must be BCHW with long side {self.model.image_encoder.img_size}." self.reset_image() self.original_size = original_image_size self.input_size = tuple(transformed_image.shape[-2:]) input_image = self.model.preprocess(transformed_image) self.features = self.model.image_encoder(input_image) self.is_image_set = True def predict( self, point_coords: Optional[np.ndarray] = None, point_labels: Optional[np.ndarray] = None, box: Optional[np.ndarray] = None, mask_input: Optional[np.ndarray] = None, multimask_output: bool = True, return_logits: bool = False, ) -> Tuple[np.ndarray, np.ndarray, np.ndarray]: """ Predict masks for the given input prompts, using the currently set image. Arguments: point_coords (np.ndarray or None): A Nx2 array of point prompts to the model. Each point is in (X,Y) in pixels. point_labels (np.ndarray or None): A length N array of labels for the point prompts. 1 indicates a foreground point and 0 indicates a background point. box (np.ndarray or None): A length 4 array given a box prompt to the model, in XYXY format. mask_input (np.ndarray): A low resolution mask input to the model, typically coming from a previous prediction iteration. Has form 1xHxW, where for SAM, H=W=256. multimask_output (bool): If true, the model will return three masks. For ambiguous input prompts (such as a single click), this will often produce better masks than a single prediction. If only a single mask is needed, the model's predicted quality score can be used to select the best mask. For non-ambiguous prompts, such as multiple input prompts, multimask_output=False can give better results. return_logits (bool): If true, returns un-thresholded masks logits instead of a binary mask. Returns: (np.ndarray): The output masks in CxHxW format, where C is the number of masks, and (H, W) is the original image size. (np.ndarray): An array of length C containing the model's predictions for the quality of each mask. (np.ndarray): An array of shape CxHxW, where C is the number of masks and H=W=256. These low resolution logits can be passed to a subsequent iteration as mask input. """ if not self.is_image_set: raise RuntimeError( "An image must be set with .set_image(...) before mask prediction." ) # Transform input prompts coords_torch, labels_torch, box_torch, mask_input_torch = None, None, None, None if point_coords is not None: assert ( point_labels is not None ), "point_labels must be supplied if point_coords is supplied." point_coords = self.transform.apply_coords(point_coords, self.original_size) coords_torch = torch.as_tensor( point_coords, dtype=torch.float, device=self.device ) labels_torch = torch.as_tensor( point_labels, dtype=torch.int, device=self.device ) coords_torch, labels_torch = coords_torch[None, :, :], labels_torch[None, :] if box is not None: box = self.transform.apply_boxes(box, self.original_size) box_torch = torch.as_tensor(box, dtype=torch.float, device=self.device) box_torch = box_torch[None, :] if mask_input is not None: mask_input_torch = torch.as_tensor( mask_input, dtype=torch.float, device=self.device ) mask_input_torch = mask_input_torch[None, :, :, :] masks, iou_predictions, low_res_masks = self.predict_torch( coords_torch, labels_torch, box_torch, mask_input_torch, multimask_output, return_logits=return_logits, ) masks_np = masks[0].detach().cpu().numpy() iou_predictions_np = iou_predictions[0].detach().cpu().numpy() low_res_masks_np = low_res_masks[0].detach().cpu().numpy() return masks_np, iou_predictions_np, low_res_masks_np @torch.no_grad() def predict_torch( self, point_coords: Optional[torch.Tensor], point_labels: Optional[torch.Tensor], boxes: Optional[torch.Tensor] = None, mask_input: Optional[torch.Tensor] = None, multimask_output: bool = True, return_logits: bool = False, ) -> Tuple[torch.Tensor, torch.Tensor, torch.Tensor]: """ Predict masks for the given input prompts, using the currently set image. Input prompts are batched torch tensors and are expected to already be transformed to the input frame using ResizeLongestSide. Arguments: point_coords (torch.Tensor or None): A BxNx2 array of point prompts to the model. Each point is in (X,Y) in pixels. point_labels (torch.Tensor or None): A BxN array of labels for the point prompts. 1 indicates a foreground point and 0 indicates a background point. boxes (np.ndarray or None): A Bx4 array given a box prompt to the model, in XYXY format. mask_input (np.ndarray): A low resolution mask input to the model, typically coming from a previous prediction iteration. Has form Bx1xHxW, where for SAM, H=W=256. Masks returned by a previous iteration of the predict method do not need further transformation. multimask_output (bool): If true, the model will return three masks. For ambiguous input prompts (such as a single click), this will often produce better masks than a single prediction. If only a single mask is needed, the model's predicted quality score can be used to select the best mask. For non-ambiguous prompts, such as multiple input prompts, multimask_output=False can give better results. return_logits (bool): If true, returns un-thresholded masks logits instead of a binary mask. Returns: (torch.Tensor): The output masks in BxCxHxW format, where C is the number of masks, and (H, W) is the original image size. (torch.Tensor): An array of shape BxC containing the model's predictions for the quality of each mask. (torch.Tensor): An array of shape BxCxHxW, where C is the number of masks and H=W=256. These low res logits can be passed to a subsequent iteration as mask input. """ if not self.is_image_set: raise RuntimeError( "An image must be set with .set_image(...) before mask prediction." ) if point_coords is not None: points = (point_coords, point_labels) else: points = None # Embed prompts sparse_embeddings, dense_embeddings = self.model.prompt_encoder( points=points, boxes=boxes, masks=mask_input, ) # Predict masks low_res_masks, iou_predictions = self.model.mask_decoder( image_embeddings=self.features, image_pe=self.model.prompt_encoder.get_dense_pe(), sparse_prompt_embeddings=sparse_embeddings, dense_prompt_embeddings=dense_embeddings, multimask_output=multimask_output, ) # Upscale the masks to the original image resolution masks = self.model.postprocess_masks( low_res_masks, self.input_size, self.original_size ) if not return_logits: masks = masks > self.model.mask_threshold return masks, iou_predictions, low_res_masks def get_image_embedding(self) -> torch.Tensor: """ Returns the image embeddings for the currently set image, with shape 1xCxHxW, where C is the embedding dimension and (H,W) are the embedding spatial dimension of SAM (typically C=256, H=W=64). """ if not self.is_image_set: raise RuntimeError( "An image must be set with .set_image(...) to generate an embedding." ) assert ( self.features is not None ), "Features must exist if an image has been set." return self.features @property def device(self) -> torch.device: return self.model.device def reset_image(self) -> None: """Resets the currently set image.""" self.is_image_set = False self.features = None self.orig_h = None self.orig_w = None self.input_h = None self.input_w = None as you can in set_torch_image, self.features is not the only thing that is stored. I think we will have to store original_size and input_size in redis aswell.
1 / 1

You're correct; both self.original_size and self.input_size are important states that get set when you run set_torch_image(). These sizes are crucial for later transformations and inference.

Since Redis is a key-value store, you can save multiple pieces of data under a single UID by nesting them in a data structure that you then serialize. Python's pickle library can serialize complex objects into byte arrays, which can be stored in Redis, and then deserialize them back into Python objects.

Here's how you could modify set_embedding and get_embedding to also include original_size and input_size:

  1. Saving to Redis
python
import pickle

def set_embedding(self, image):
    self.predictor.set_image(image)
    uid = str(uuid.uuid4())
    if self.predictor.features is not None:
        data_to_store = {
            'features': self.predictor.features.clone().cpu().numpy(),
            'original_size': self.predictor.original_size,
            'input_size': self.predictor.input_size
        }
        serialized_data = pickle.dumps(data_to_store)
        self.redis_client.set(uid, serialized_data)
        logger.info(f"Saved embedding for UID: {uid}")
    return uid
  1. Loading from Redis
python
def get_embedding(self, uid):
    serialized_data = self.redis_client.get(uid)
    if serialized_data is None:
        raise ValueError(f"No embedding found for UID {uid}")
    data_loaded = pickle.loads(serialized_data)
    features = torch.from_numpy(data_loaded['features']).to(self.sam.device)
    original_size = data_loaded['original_size']
    input_size = data_loaded['input_size']
    return features, original_size, input_size

You would also need to modify the code that calls get_embedding to handle the multiple returned values.

Please note that pickle comes with its own set of security concerns if you're loading data from an untrusted source, but since you are controlling both the saving and loading, it should be fine in this context.

1 / 1
if I have this in a file name new_predictor.py in the same file as handler.py: # Copyright (c) Meta Platforms, Inc. and affiliates. # All rights reserved. # This source code is licensed under the license found in the # LICENSE file in the root directory of this source tree. import numpy as np import torch from segment_anything.modeling import Sam from typing import Optional, Tuple from segment_anything.utils.transforms import ResizeLongestSide class CustomSamPredictor: def __init__( self, sam_model: Sam, ) -> None: """ Uses SAM to calculate the image embedding for an image, and then allow repeated, efficient mask prediction given prompts. Arguments: sam_model (Sam): The model to use for mask prediction. """ super().__init__() self.model = sam_model self.transform = ResizeLongestSide(sam_model.image_encoder.img_size) self.reset_image() def set_image( self, image: np.ndarray, image_format: str = "RGB", ) -> None: """ Calculates the image embeddings for the provided image, allowing masks to be predicted with the 'predict' method. Arguments: image (np.ndarray): The image for calculating masks. Expects an image in HWC uint8 format, with pixel values in [0, 255]. image_format (str): The color format of the image, in ['RGB', 'BGR']. """ assert image_format in [ "RGB", "BGR", ], f"image_format must be in ['RGB', 'BGR'], is {image_format}." if image_format != self.model.image_format: image = image[..., ::-1] # Transform the image to the form expected by the model input_image = self.transform.apply_image(image) input_image_torch = torch.as_tensor(input_image, device=self.device) input_image_torch = input_image_torch.permute(2, 0, 1).contiguous()[ None, :, :, : ] self.set_torch_image(input_image_torch, image.shape[:2]) @torch.no_grad() def set_torch_image( self, transformed_image: torch.Tensor, original_image_size: Tuple[int, ...], ) -> None: """ Calculates the image embeddings for the provided image, allowing masks to be predicted with the 'predict' method. Expects the input image to be already transformed to the format expected by the model. Arguments: transformed_image (torch.Tensor): The input image, with shape 1x3xHxW, which has been transformed with ResizeLongestSide. original_image_size (tuple(int, int)): The size of the image before transformation, in (H, W) format. """ assert ( len(transformed_image.shape) == 4 and transformed_image.shape[1] == 3 and max(*transformed_image.shape[2:]) == self.model.image_encoder.img_size ), f"set_torch_image input must be BCHW with long side {self.model.image_encoder.img_size}." self.reset_image() self.original_size = original_image_size self.input_size = tuple(transformed_image.shape[-2:]) input_image = self.model.preprocess(transformed_image) self.features = self.model.image_encoder(input_image) self.is_image_set = True def predict( self, point_coords: Optional[np.ndarray] = None, point_labels: Optional[np.ndarray] = None, box: Optional[np.ndarray] = None, mask_input: Optional[np.ndarray] = None, multimask_output: bool = True, return_logits: bool = False, ) -> Tuple[np.ndarray, np.ndarray, np.ndarray]: """ Predict masks for the given input prompts, using the currently set image. Arguments: point_coords (np.ndarray or None): A Nx2 array of point prompts to the model. Each point is in (X,Y) in pixels. point_labels (np.ndarray or None): A length N array of labels for the point prompts. 1 indicates a foreground point and 0 indicates a background point. box (np.ndarray or None): A length 4 array given a box prompt to the model, in XYXY format. mask_input (np.ndarray): A low resolution mask input to the model, typically coming from a previous prediction iteration. Has form 1xHxW, where for SAM, H=W=256. multimask_output (bool): If true, the model will return three masks. For ambiguous input prompts (such as a single click), this will often produce better masks than a single prediction. If only a single mask is needed, the model's predicted quality score can be used to select the best mask. For non-ambiguous prompts, such as multiple input prompts, multimask_output=False can give better results. return_logits (bool): If true, returns un-thresholded masks logits instead of a binary mask. Returns: (np.ndarray): The output masks in CxHxW format, where C is the number of masks, and (H, W) is the original image size. (np.ndarray): An array of length C containing the model's predictions for the quality of each mask. (np.ndarray): An array of shape CxHxW, where C is the number of masks and H=W=256. These low resolution logits can be passed to a subsequent iteration as mask input. """ if not self.is_image_set: raise RuntimeError( "An image must be set with .set_image(...) before mask prediction." ) # Transform input prompts coords_torch, labels_torch, box_torch, mask_input_torch = None, None, None, None if point_coords is not None: assert ( point_labels is not None ), "point_labels must be supplied if point_coords is supplied." point_coords = self.transform.apply_coords(point_coords, self.original_size) coords_torch = torch.as_tensor( point_coords, dtype=torch.float, device=self.device ) labels_torch = torch.as_tensor( point_labels, dtype=torch.int, device=self.device ) coords_torch, labels_torch = coords_torch[None, :, :], labels_torch[None, :] if box is not None: box = self.transform.apply_boxes(box, self.original_size) box_torch = torch.as_tensor(box, dtype=torch.float, device=self.device) box_torch = box_torch[None, :] if mask_input is not None: mask_input_torch = torch.as_tensor( mask_input, dtype=torch.float, device=self.device ) mask_input_torch = mask_input_torch[None, :, :, :] masks, iou_predictions, low_res_masks = self.predict_torch( coords_torch, labels_torch, box_torch, mask_input_torch, multimask_output, return_logits=return_logits, ) masks_np = masks[0].detach().cpu().numpy() iou_predictions_np = iou_predictions[0].detach().cpu().numpy() low_res_masks_np = low_res_masks[0].detach().cpu().numpy() return masks_np, iou_predictions_np, low_res_masks_np @torch.no_grad() def predict_torch( self, point_coords: Optional[torch.Tensor], point_labels: Optional[torch.Tensor], boxes: Optional[torch.Tensor] = None, mask_input: Optional[torch.Tensor] = None, multimask_output: bool = True, return_logits: bool = False, ) -> Tuple[torch.Tensor, torch.Tensor, torch.Tensor]: """ Predict masks for the given input prompts, using the currently set image. Input prompts are batched torch tensors and are expected to already be transformed to the input frame using ResizeLongestSide. Arguments: point_coords (torch.Tensor or None): A BxNx2 array of point prompts to the model. Each point is in (X,Y) in pixels. point_labels (torch.Tensor or None): A BxN array of labels for the point prompts. 1 indicates a foreground point and 0 indicates a background point. boxes (np.ndarray or None): A Bx4 array given a box prompt to the model, in XYXY format. mask_input (np.ndarray): A low resolution mask input to the model, typically coming from a previous prediction iteration. Has form Bx1xHxW, where for SAM, H=W=256. Masks returned by a previous iteration of the predict method do not need further transformation. multimask_output (bool): If true, the model will return three masks. For ambiguous input prompts (such as a single click), this will often produce better masks than a single prediction. If only a single mask is needed, the model's predicted quality score can be used to select the best mask. For non-ambiguous prompts, such as multiple input prompts, multimask_output=False can give better results. return_logits (bool): If true, returns un-thresholded masks logits instead of a binary mask. Returns: (torch.Tensor): The output masks in BxCxHxW format, where C is the number of masks, and (H, W) is the original image size. (torch.Tensor): An array of shape BxC containing the model's predictions for the quality of each mask. (torch.Tensor): An array of shape BxCxHxW, where C is the number of masks and H=W=256. These low res logits can be passed to a subsequent iteration as mask input. """ if not self.is_image_set: raise RuntimeError( "An image must be set with .set_image(...) before mask prediction." ) if point_coords is not None: points = (point_coords, point_labels) else: points = None # Embed prompts sparse_embeddings, dense_embeddings = self.model.prompt_encoder( points=points, boxes=boxes, masks=mask_input, ) # Predict masks low_res_masks, iou_predictions = self.model.mask_decoder( image_embeddings=self.features, image_pe=self.model.prompt_encoder.get_dense_pe(), sparse_prompt_embeddings=sparse_embeddings, dense_prompt_embeddings=dense_embeddings, multimask_output=multimask_output, ) # Upscale the masks to the original image resolution masks = self.model.postprocess_masks( low_res_masks, self.input_size, self.original_size ) if not return_logits: masks = masks > self.model.mask_threshold return masks, iou_predictions, low_res_masks def get_image_embedding(self) -> torch.Tensor: """ Returns the image embeddings for the currently set image, with shape 1xCxHxW, where C is the embedding dimension and (H,W) are the embedding spatial dimension of SAM (typically C=256, H=W=64). """ if not self.is_image_set: raise RuntimeError( "An image must be set with .set_image(...) to generate an embedding." ) assert ( self.features is not None ), "Features must exist if an image has been set." return self.features @property def device(self) -> torch.device: return self.model.device def reset_image(self) -> None: """Resets the currently set image.""" self.is_image_set = False self.features = None self.orig_h = None self.orig_w = None self.input_h = None self.input_w = None how do I import it in handler?
1 / 1

You can import the CustomSamPredictor class in your handler.py file using the following import statement, assuming both files are in the same directory:

python
from new_predictor import CustomSamPredictor

After importing, you can use CustomSamPredictor just like any other class in your handler.py.

Example:

python
# handler.py

from new_predictor import CustomSamPredictor
# ... other imports ...

class MyHandler:
    def __init__(self):
        # Initialize SAM model (assume this is available)
        self.sam_model = Sam(...)  
        
        # Initialize CustomSamPredictor
        self.custom_sam_predictor = CustomSamPredictor(self.sam_model)
        
    # ... rest of the code ...

This way, the CustomSamPredictor class will be accessible in your handler.py, and you can use its methods as needed.
